sub_topic: Understanding the role of Cooper pairs in superconductivity
message_1: "How do Cooper pairs contribute to the phenomenon of zero electrical resistance in superconductors?"
message_2:
Cooper pairs play a crucial role in the phenomenon of zero electrical resistance in superconductors. Superconductivity is a state in which a material exhibits zero electrical resistance and perfect diamagnetism below a certain critical temperature. This phenomenon was first observed by Heike Kamerlingh Onnes in 1911.

In 1957, John Bardeen, Leon Cooper, and Robert Schrieffer developed the BCS (Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer) theory to explain the microscopic mechanism behind superconductivity. The key concept in this theory is the formation of Cooper pairs.

Cooper pairs are formed when two electrons with opposite spins and momenta attract each other through an indirect interaction mediated by the lattice vibrations (phonons) in the material. This attractive interaction overcomes the natural repulsion between electrons due to their negative charges. The result is a bound state of two electrons, known as a Cooper pair.

In a superconductor, a large number of Cooper pairs are formed, and they condense into a single quantum state known as the BCS ground state. This state is characterized by a unique quantum wave function that describes the collective behavior of all the Cooper pairs in the system.

The zero electrical resistance in superconductors can be understood as a consequence of the coherent motion of these Cooper pairs. When an external electric field is applied to a superconductor, all the Cooper pairs move coherently without any scattering or energy loss. This is because the energy gap between the BCS ground state and the excited states is larger than the energy of the lattice vibrations (phonons) and impurities that could potentially scatter the electrons.

Since the Cooper pairs move without scattering, there is no energy dissipation, and hence, no electrical resistance in the superconductor. This coherent motion of Cooper pairs is what leads to the remarkable phenomenon of zero electrical resistance in superconductors.
